An annual financial report of The Johns Hopkins
University, made public today, revealed that the university's current income for the fiscal year 1957-58 rose to
$40,006,000, a net increase of $4,254,000 over the previous
fiscal year.
During the same period, current expenditures and
appropriations totalled $39,802,000, or $3,774,000 more
than the 1956-57 fiscal year.
The report, submitted to the university's trustees by
Henry S. Baker, treasurer, showed, in a summary comparison with previous years, that annual current income
had more than quadrupled in ten years, rising from
$8,983,000 in 1947-48 to $40,006,000 in 1957-58.

Surplus Again
In that decade, the University

June 30th was $205,000.
During the 1957-58 fiscal year,

and general purposes increased
by $1,933,000 over the previous
year, and endowment income increased by $334,000.
Tuition Rise Helps
These increases, as well as
rises in income from tuition and
heightened contract research
activity, accounted for the record
income,.Mr. Baker explained in a
preface to the detailed report.
A breakdown of the total income of $40,006,000 showed that
$3,304,000 was derived from fees;
$2,419,000 from endowment income for educational and general
purposes; $1,777,000 for reimbursement of indirect costs incurred on research projects;

The DSRC has acted to stop
the vandalism by issuing a warning to a first violator and then
taking trial action to review the
actions of a habitual violator.
To The Lounge!
In the past, week Tonkin has
also acted to coordinate with
Steve Broening and the Interfraternity
Board
to
abolish
rushing in the halls of the dormitories and Minimize it in the
court yard and the snack bar.
The DSRC also asked the fraternities to show consideration
for the non-rushee's study privileges by rushing his roommate
in the
lounge.

Tonkin also called upon the
IFB to enlist fraternity aid in
exhibiting restraint in serving
alcoholic beverages to dormitory
freshmen for "the destruction
to the dormitories that has resulted from freshmen returning
intoxicated from rush parties ...
has been considerable."
"No Complaints"
Tonkin noted that in contrast
to previous years, rushing in the
dormitories has been acceptable
and "engendered no complaints."
"We hope to work through the
fraternities to lessen the damage
done by the freshmen, as well as
the upperclassmen," noted Tonkin.

EXPANSION PROGRAM

CAREER OPPORTUNITIES
The location of your first assignment
with DuPont depends on your qualifications and on the openings in your
field, but every effort is made to match
the job and the location with your
preference. The chances for a successful match are good.

Don't forget the "extras" of an employee benefit program when you compare the job offers and salaries of
different companies. At Du Pont,these
extras mean added income that doesn't
always meet the eye. They include
life insurance, group hospitalization
and sprgical coverage, accident and
health insurance, pension plan and
paid vacation.
In addition, the Company sponsors
a thrift plan. After two years of service, for every dollar you invest in
U..S. Savings Bonds the Company sets
aside 25 cents for the purchase of
common stock in your name. Roughly,
60,000 of our employees are now participating in this plan.
If you have specific questions on
Du Pont benefits, just send them to
me. I'll be happy to try to answer
them. E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.
(Inc.), Room 12421 Nemours Building, Wilmington 98, Delaware.

Today there are men and women
carving out careers with Du Pont at
more than 75 plants and nearly 100
laboratories spread throughout 26
states. Last year the Company spent
$220 million for new plants and for
increased capacities at existing installations. This year new plants have
already been put into operation in
Virginia and Michigan. Six more
are under construction. Others are
planned for the near future.
Most DuPont units, it is true, are
located east of the Mississippi. Company headquarters,for example, along
with many labs and plants, are located
in and around Wilmington, Delaware,
which is a pleasant residential area
within easy reach of Washington,
Philadelphia and New York. But there
are also plants, and laboratories in
California, Iowa, Kansas and Texas,
and plants in Colorado, Missouri and
Washington.
Wherever you're assigned, you'll be
proud of the Du Pont Company both
on and off the job. You'll find the
people you work with friendly, stimulating, and active in the life of the
community.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCT. 17, 1958 H

War Breaks Out In Nines Hall
Over Ham Radio Interference
The Amateur Radio Club appears to be interfering with some
of the physics department's experiments, and, as a result, that
department may soon be trying
to oust the club from its room in
Ames Hall.
No one is certain exactly What
the trouble is, although the
physics people think it may be
the fault of the club's antenna,
which runs between Ames 'and
Roland Halls. Members of the
Radio Club are inclined to believe the physics department
does not have its experiments
properly shielded.
To decide the exact reason for
the interference, a test will be

DSRC Proposal

run and supervised by Dr. Mandansky of the physics department and Dr. Hamburger, advisor of the Club. If the interference is the fault of the club's
gear, which is a powerful 1,000
watts, they will start looking for
a new location, probably in the
dorms or some area away from
the engineering classrooms.
Another solution is, to 'reduce
the power, but Dick Chambers,
president, expresses the club's
sentiments on this very positively: "We don't want to lose
any of our power. We're proud
of our 1,000 watts. It is the
maximum allowed by law."
Each year the Club competes

in two contests. One is a sweepstake sponsored by the Amateur
Radio League, covering two
weekends and 20 radio hours
during which they log as manY
amateurs in the U.S. and possessions as possible. Last year
they logged every state except
Wyoming. The other is the
"DX", "distance" in radio slang,
contest which is the same except
they try to log as many foreign
countries as possible. Last year
an astounding 84 countries were
logged.
Once a year the club migrates
to the seashore for a partY,
otherwise known as the "Orgy'',
Of course, being radio bugs, they
take their equipment with them,
Howevbr, most of the club's
activities are very informal,
Each noon hour the members
can be found hunched over the
rig talking to fellow amateurS
all over the world. The only requirement for admission is aV

The perennial problem of dormitory vandalism has
reached proportions which, if not remedied soon, must
necessarily result in serious administrative infringement

community spirit which would engender respect for self,
others and University. This is not necessarily regrettable,
but is lamentable in this case.
Additionally, the common room of the old dormitory
has been usurped by the dining room and replaced by
barren, cold entry lounges whicfi are seldom used for
communal purposes, whose recreational facilities are limited and vandalized, and which provide no constructive
outlet for energies which wane destructive when pent up.
The best remedy for vandalism, however, lies with
the very students who perpetuate the destruction. It is
a platitude of speech, but not of action, that freedom
demands a noncommitant responsibility.
If the students do not act, the administration has a
right and duty to imposc unpopular, undesirable, and, in
some cases, unneeded restraints.
A third remedy lies with a major reconstruction of
the DSRC. The popular election system naturally seeks
weak representatives who are reluctant and/or unable
to govern, and breeds a lack of respect for the Council.
It should be replaced by a quasi-elective, quasi-appointive
system which should be centered, where possible, around
upperclassmen and should operate on an individual House,
rather than an all-dorm, basis.
It is clear that the DSRC is too ineffective to govern
four hundred students. The Houses themselves present
more suitable units for government because they are
familiar with their residents and peculiar problems, and
have their field of jurisdiction reduced to manageable
size. While the Houses deal with purely internal problems, the DSRC should handle only policies and problems
involving all Houses and students.

Yes, we do emphasize wide participation in our
rtit
theathletic program at Johns Hopkins. The whole structure
of the athletic policy is oriented in that direction—no
athletic scholarships, no alumni pressure on the coaches,
etc.
Well, no, it hasn't always been that way. Back in the
twenties, we played such gridiron giants as Penn, Maryland, Syracuse, Princeton, and Columbia. Of course, we
charged admission then, and we gave out more scholarships
than the Fuller Brush Company gave away free samples.
Is equal emphasis given to all sports? Certainly! It
must be acknowledged that the soccer team wasn't provided with meals before school started, as the football team
was. However, there really wasn't enough to go around.
Why didn't they divide the money equally between the two
teams? Well, you just have to understand that the emphasis given to some sports is more equal than that given
to others'.

dependent upon the fraternities, but this situation is due
b
more to the convenience of the fraternity setup than to
bias. Attempts have been made to organize the dormitory

An annual financial report of The Johns Hopkins
University, made public today, revealed that the university's current income for the fiscal year 1957-58 rose to
$40,006,000, a net increase of $4,254,000 over the previous
fiscal year.
During the same period, current expenditures and
appropriations totalled $39,802,000, or $3,774,000 more
than the 1956-57 fiscal year.
The report, submitted to the university's trustees by
Henry S. Baker, treasurer, showed, in a summary comparison with previous years, that annual current income
had more than quadrupled in ten years, rising from
$8,983,000 in 1947-48 to $40,006,000 in 1957-58.

The location of your first assignment

different companies. At Du Pont,these
extras mean added income that doesn't
always meet the eye. They include
life insurance, group hospitalization

health insurance, pension plan and

carving out careers with Du Pont at
more than 75 plants and nearly 100

states. Last year the Company spent
$220 million for new plants and for
increased capacities at existing installations. This year new plants have
already been put into operation in
Virginia and Michigan. Six more
are under construction. Others are
planned for the near future.

located east of the Mississippi. Company headquarters,for example, along

in and around Wilmington, Delaware,
which is a pleasant residential area
within easy reach of Washington,
Philadelphia and New York. But there
are also plants, and laboratories in
California, Iowa, Kansas and Texas,
and plants in Colorado, Missouri and
Washington.
Wherever you're assigned, you'll be
proud of the Du Pont Company both
on and off the job. You'll find the
people you work with friendly, stimulating, and active in the life of the
community.

Over Ham Radio Interference
The Amateur Radio Club appears to be interfering with some
of the physics department's experiments, and, as a result, that
department may soon be trying
to oust the club from its room in
Ames Hall.
No one is certain exactly What
the trouble is, although the
physics people think it may be
the fault of the club's antenna,
which runs between Ames 'and
Roland Halls. Members of the
Radio Club are inclined to believe the physics department
does not have its experiments
properly shielded.
To decide the exact reason for
the interference, a test will be

a new location, probably in the
dorms or some area away from
the engineering classrooms.
Another solution is, to 'reduce
the power, but Dick Chambers,
president, expresses the club's
sentiments on this very positively: "We don't want to lose
any of our power. We're proud
of our 1,000 watts. It is the
maximum allowed by law."

they try to log as many foreign
countries as possible. Last year
an astounding 84 countries were
logged.

several of the plays of ShakesThese causes all have a prior cause: a lack of identification of the student with the University. There is no
community spirit which would engender respect for self,
others and University. This is not necessarily regrettable,
but is lamentable in this case.
Additionally, the common room of the old dormitory
has been usurped by the dining room and replaced by
barren, cold entry lounges whicfi are seldom used for
communal purposes, whose recreational facilities are limited and vandalized, and which provide no constructive
outlet for energies which wane destructive when pent up.
The best remedy for vandalism, however, lies with
the very students who perpetuate the destruction. It is
a platitude of speech, but not of action, that freedom
demands a noncommitant responsibility.
If the students do not act, the administration has a
right and duty to imposc unpopular, undesirable, and, in
some cases, unneeded restraints.
A third remedy lies with a major reconstruction of
the DSRC. The popular election system naturally seeks
weak representatives who are reluctant and/or unable
to govern, and breeds a lack of respect for the Council.
It should be replaced by a quasi-elective, quasi-appointive
system which should be centered, where possible, around
upperclassmen and should operate on an individual House,
rather than an all-dorm, basis.
It is clear that the DSRC is too ineffective to govern
four hundred students. The Houses themselves present
more suitable units for government because they are
familiar with their residents and peculiar problems, and
have their field of jurisdiction reduced to manageable
size. While the Houses deal with purely internal problems, the DSRC should handle only policies and problems
involving all Houses and students.

The House officers should be juniors or seniors whose
voluntary candidacy is endorsed or prompted by the administration officers concerned with the dorms, but elected
by all their House residents. Thus, they would be experienced enough to be familiar with the problems, able
enough to counsel and rebuke, and responsible enough
to correct the present system's weaknesses and abuses.
The DSRC, in turn, should be an executive committee
made up of about seven House officers, elected by all
dormitory residents in a general election. A limited
democracy in dorm government would replace all aspects
of a system which is now plagued by too much democracy.

By STAN IIANDMAKER, Sports Editor

Yes, we do emphasize wide participation in our
rtit
theathletic program at Johns Hopkins. The whole structure
of the athletic policy is oriented in that direction—no
athletic scholarships, no alumni pressure on the coaches,
etc.
Well, no, it hasn't always been that way. Back in the
twenties, we played such gridiron giants as Penn, Maryland, Syracuse, Princeton, and Columbia. Of course, we
charged admission then, and we gave out more scholarships
than the Fuller Brush Company gave away free samples.
Is equal emphasis given to all sports? Certainly! It
must be acknowledged that the soccer team wasn't provided with meals before school started, as the football team
was. However, there really wasn't enough to go around.
Why didn't they divide the money equally between the two
teams? Well, you just have to understand that the emphasis given to some sports is more equal than that given
to others'.
Yes, the intramural program is to a large extent
dependent upon the fraternities, but this situation is due
b
more to the convenience of the fraternity setup than to
bias. Attempts have been made to organize the dormitory
ho ses, but
thus far enthusiasm has been noticeably lacking
on the part of the dorm residents. It seems that many
u. ndergraduates would rather spend their free time indulgIng In Calypso ice cream in the snack bar than get an
afternoon of football in.
It is true that if half the student body should decide
to be
gung ho and participate, the facilities would prove
.il!adequate. And the independent lacrosse league was a
hit overcrowded last spring. However, there is talk in the
Wind about a new gym. No, it is highly unlikely that we'll
s_ee such a thing while we're still undergraduates. These
things take time, you know.

Though the Jays emerged victorious, Coach Mickey Cochrane
was not pleased "with our lack
of hustle in the first half of the
game., The team definitely has
more than it showed. It could
have gone either way in the last
half, and we were lucky to win."
Cochraners comments must
have had an effect, for their was
no lack of hustle evident this
past Wednesday, as the Jays
broke open a 1-0 game with
three unassisted goals in the last
period to trounce Towson State.
DeSwann, assisted by Don
Evenson, scored what proved to
be the only goal the Blue Jays
needed in the last seconds of the
first quarter. After two scoreless tension-packed periods, the
Towson team seemed to crumple
to pieces behind the pressure of
the Blue attack, as Larry Ey,
Harold Standiford, and Duffany
scored in rapid succession to ice
the victory.
Credit must go to the whole
Hopkins team, but especially to
the stout Blue Jay defense of
Harry Weitzel, Lee Carter, and
Jim Payne, and Goalie Skip
Poole who staved off a great
many serious Towson threats at
